metadata.title: Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order
metadata.source: San Mateo County Court Mermaid diagram (Restraining Orders-2025-12-23-013154.mmd)
metadata.description: Complete flow for Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Orders

EA0.text: Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order

EA1.text: A judge can grant this restraining order to protect someone who is elderly (65 or older) or a dependent adult (18–64 with a disability) from abuse, neglect, abandonment, or harassment. Once granted, police can enforce the order.

EA2.text:
This restraining order can include:
• No contact
• Stay a certain distance away
• Move out (if the person lives with the protected person)
• Counseling or anger management
• Cannot own or have firearms, ammunition, or body armor
    • Other protections ordered by the judge

EA3.text: Who can ask for this restraining order?

EA4.text:
• The elder or dependent adult (for themself)
• The elder/dependent adult’s conservator or trustee
• Their attorney or guardian ad litem
    • A representative of Adult Protective Services (APS)

EA5.text: Where to file in San Mateo County

EA6.text:
These cases are handled by the Probate Department.
    If the person needing protection is 65 or older, the case is filed in Probate.

EA_Start.text: Start an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order

EA_Step1.text: Step 1: Fill out the required court forms

EA_Forms.text:
Required forms:
• EA-100 — Request for Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Orders
• CLETS-001 — Confidential CLETS Information
• EA-109 — Notice of Court Hearing
    • EA-110 — Temporary Restraining Order (ONLY if asking for immediate protection)

EA_NoFee.text: There is no court filing fee to request an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order.

EA_Copies.text:
Make at least 2 copies of everything:
• One for you
• One for the restrained person
    The original is for the court.

EA_Step3.text: Step 3: Take your paperwork to the Probate Clerk’s Office

EA_JudgeReview.text:
The clerk will send your paperwork to a judge for review.
If the judge grants temporary orders, the judge will:
• Sign EA-110 (if requested)
    • Set a hearing date on EA-109

EA_Service.text:
Service rules:
• Someone over 18 (not you) must serve the papers
• The San Mateo County Sheriff will attempt service of process for restraining orders free of charge
    • Sheriff’s Office: 300 Bradford Street, 1st Floor, Redwood City, CA

EA_Step5.text: Step 5: Go to court on the hearing date listed on EA-109

EA_AfterHearing.text:
If the judge grants the restraining order after the hearing, the long-term order is issued on:
    • EA-130 — Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order After Hearing

EA_Read.text: If someone filed court papers asking for an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse restraining order against you, carefully read all the papers you were served.

EA_Respond.text: Respond to an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order (If You Were Served)

EA_Check109.text: Check EA-109 (Notice of Court Hearing). This form lists your court date, time, and location.

EA_CourtNeeded.text:
If you do not agree with the restraining order, you must go to court.
    At the hearing, the judge decides whether to issue an order that can last up to 5 years.

EA_Check110.text: Did the judge sign EA-110 (Temporary Restraining Order)?

EA_ObeyTRO.text:
You must follow every order in EA-110 immediately.
    If you do not, you could be arrested and charged with a crime.

EA_ResponseOpt.text: Would you like to respond in writing before court? This is optional.

EA120.text:
Fill out EA-120 — Response to Request for Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order.
    Attach any evidence you want the judge to review (texts, emails, photos).

EA_PrepCourt.text:
Prepare for court:
Bring copies of all papers, your evidence, and notes of what you want to say.
    Arrive early.

EA_ServeResp.text:
Have someone 18+ (not you) serve your response as required.
    File proof of service with the court before the hearing.

EA_GoCourt.text: Go to court on the date listed in EA-109.

EA_RenewCheck.text: Do you already have EA-130 and it is going to expire?

EA_Renew.text: Renew an Elder or Dependent Adult Abuse Restraining Order

EA_RenewWindow.text: You can ask to renew the restraining order up to 3 months before the expiration date listed on EA-130 (page 1, item 4).

EA_RenewForms.text:
Required renewal forms:
• EA-700 — Request to Renew Restraining Order
• EA-710 — Notice of Hearing to Renew Restraining Order
    Attach a copy of your current EA-130 to EA-700.

EA_RenewCopies.text: Make at least 2 copies (one for you, one for the restrained person).

EA_RenewFile.text:
Step 2: Take your paperwork to the Probate Clerk.
The clerk will file the papers and set a hearing date on EA-710.
    Your current restraining order is extended until that hearing date.

EA_RenewServe.text:
Step 3: Serve the restrained person with the renewal papers.
Sheriff service is free in San Mateo County:
    300 Bradford Street, 1st Floor, Redwood City, CA

EA_RenewCourt.text:
Step 4: Go to court on the date listed in EA-710.
    The judge decides whether to renew the restraining order.
